title: How to Cook Artichoke Hearts

steps.headline: Select artichokes that are heavy, firm, and have dark green leaves.
steps.description: The artichoke should feel heavy for its size. When you squeeze it, it should feel firm and make a small squeaking sound. Some leaves may be more tightly or loosely packed than others, which is fine, just make sure they are dark green and not cracked or shriveled. You will get about 2 ounces (57 g) of edible flesh from each medium-large artichoke that you purchase. Plan for this when making your selections.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the artichokes if you aren't using them immediately.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to carefully cut off a small portion of the stem. Wet the freshly-cut stem and store the whole artichoke in an airtight plastic bag or container in the back of refrigerator. You may store the artichokes for up to 5 days, but they are typically better if they are eaten within the first day or 2 of purchase.

steps.headline: Wash the artichoke under cold running water.
steps.description: Allow the water to run through the leaves so you get a good, thorough cleaning. If you have a vegetable brush, use it to gently scrub-down the whole artichoke to remove the filmy natural coating it produces while growing.

steps.headline: Use a stainless steel knife to cut off the top one-third of the artichoke.
steps.description: Using a serrated knife will make cutting through the leaves quite a bit easier. Lay the artichoke on its side, and carefully saw back and forth until you cut all the way through to the other end. It is very important that you use a stainless steel knife to cut the artichoke. Iron, aluminum, or carbon will discolor the artichoke and turn it blue or black.

steps.headline: Cut ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) off the stem and remove the bottom leaves.
steps.description: Use your kitchen knife to cut a thick slice off the bottom of the stem. Pull off the leaves near the stem and the outer leaves surrounding the bottom of the artichoke. Remove the leaves until you reach the yellowish-green center. Many people remove the entire stem, but don't do it! The stem is an extension of the heart, so you definitely want to save this part for eating. If the leaves near the base are too hard to pull off, use a small paring knife to cut away those tough, woody parts.

steps.headline: Scoop out the hairy, fibrous portion from the center of the artichoke.
steps.description: Holding the artichoke firmly in place with one hand, use a spoon or melon-baller to scrape along the inside center of the artichoke. You only want to remove the hairy, fibrous portion (which is called the choke). Discard the choke once you remove it—it isn't edible.

steps.headline: Squeeze the juice from 1 lemon into a large bowl of cold water.
steps.description: Select a bowl that is large enough to hold all of your artichokes and fill it with cold water. Cut a fresh lemon in half and squeeze the juice into the water. Put the lemon halves in the bowl of water as well.

steps.headline: Rub lemon over the artichoke before placing it in the lemon water.
steps.description: Rubbing extra lemon on the artichokes will further prevent browning. After you have all of the cut surfaces covered in lemon, place the artichoke in the bowl of lemon water while you finishing preparing the others.

steps.headline: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil over medium heat.
steps.description: Use a stainless steel or enamel pot to avoid discoloring the artichokes. After you have placed the pot on the stove, add a big squeeze of lemon juice for flavoring and to help prevent browning.

steps.headline: Simmer the prepared artichoke hearts for about 15 minutes.
steps.description: Drop the artichoke hearts into the water slowly to avoid splashing. Once they are boiling, reduce the heat, cover the pot, and simmer the artichokes for about 15-20 minutes. The water will stop boiling once the vegetables are added. Allow the water temperature to come up again and return to a hard boil before you begin timing.

steps.headline: Pull a leaf from the center of the artichoke to check for doneness.
steps.description: Use a slotted spoon to carefully lift one of the artichoke hearts out of the water. Use your other hand to gently pull a leaf from the center of the artichoke. If the leaf comes out easily, the artichokes are done cooking and you can remove them from the water. Place the artichokes upside down on a dish to drain. If the leaf does not pull out easily, continue cooking the artichokes for another 5 minutes or so and then check again.

steps.headline: Eat the artichoke hearts or use them in your favorite recipes.
steps.description: Leave the artichoke hearts as they are and serve them with a meal, or cut them into small chunks or slices to add to your favorite dip or pasta recipe. Refrigerate leftover artichoke hearts within 2 hours of cooking. Store them in an airtight container for 3-5 days.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 400 °F (204 °C) and line a baking sheet.
steps.description: If you know that your oven cooks warmer or cooler, then adjust the temperature as necessary based on your experiences. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. If you don't have parchment paper, that's okay—there will just be more clean up later.

steps.headline: Cut the artichoke hearts in half and place them in a bowl to season them.
steps.description: Drizzle olive oil over the artichoke hearts. Season the artichokes based on your taste preferences. Many people choose spices such as thyme, salt, pepper, and garlic, but feel free to experiment here. For a savory flavor, try sprinkling the artichoke hearts with grated parmesan cheese.

steps.headline: Roast the artichokes for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Lay the artichokes, cut-side down, on a baking sheet and put them in the oven. Bake them for about 15 minutes and then turn them over. Continue baking for about 15 more minutes or until the artichokes turn golden brown. Some ovens vary in temperature, so keep an eye on the artichokes and adjust the cooking time as needed. When they are golden brown, they are ready to eat!

steps.headline: Serve the roasted artichoke hearts hot or add them to other recipes.
steps.description: You can drizzle a little more olive oil over the top before serving, or try them on pizza, salad, or in your favorite pasta recipe. Store any leftover roasted artichoke hearts in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3-5 days.
